prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Location of trial

para.paratext: The Panel has considered the probable location of trial in determining what district may be an appropriate transferee district.[1] This is not a factor relied on by the Panel routinely, but the Panel may be able to select a forum that is most desirable for this reason and that is also equally appropriate under the Panel's more heavily relied-upon factors.

This is another factor that correlates with other factors and probably has more relevance today than in prior years. A district where a greater number of actions were originally filed reflects the preference of each plaintiff filing there, and assuming that the court has subject-matter jurisdiction and personal jurisdiction over the parties, the case can proceed to trial there. This would obviate any remand. Districts that have a defendant's headquarters would be more like be such a district. Districts where cases had been transferred pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) would also be districts where trial will be held.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376, 382 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
